{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3494301,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T01:34:49.437Z","cooked":"

So before we actually have our elevator, I have been beginning to look into and code some simple parts of it. We PLAN on using our elevator to actually lift us (shallow cage) so we need some sort of gear ratio and plan on using two WCP Single Stage Gearbox – WestCoast Products with the 6.88 gear ratio and two neos per gearbox (seems a tad bit excessive to me but whatever works), and we’re using the PRE-ORDER BATCH 2: Thrifty Elevator Stage Kit - 2 Stage.

What I’m getting at is I was looking at the REV ION Starter Bot’s code and they use something called MAXMotion yet they only use one motor with it. Does MAXMotion work with multiple motors, I didn’t see anywhere where it says it does. Also is it a good idea to use in the first place?

Also I kinda want yalls opinion on using 4 neos for our elevator.

You would probably want to use MaxMotion on a single controller, and then set your other motors to follow it!

10219Ryba:

Also I kinda want yalls opinion on using 4 neos for our elevator

I can’t comment on the other stuff but this seems very excessive. I’d recommend having just two motors with a higher gear ratio. It will slow down your elevator but it would allow the climb to happen. However if you do end up going with the 4 NEO design I still don’t know how good it would be for climbing.

image946×1251 72.5 KB

According to recalc it would pull up a full weight robot theoretically but the data does seem iffy to me. It will also just be super taxing on your battery to have four motors moving a lot all match along with whatever drivebase and manipulator you have.

I am by no means an expert so if someone smarter comes along who disagrees I’d take their word over mine.

Edit: That data is for a full weight robot, if yours is more around 100ish pounds the data does look a bit more promising.

See this is exactly what I was thinking, however, I know that the wcp gearbox doesn’t design gearboxes with a higher gear ratio for the neo shaft.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T02:22:13.351Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":19.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483905,"topic_slug":"rev-maxmotion-question","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51417,"username":"CuteRedpandas","name":"Jared Van Horn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/rev-maxmotion-question/483905/4","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3494414,"name":"Jared Van Horn","username":"CuteRedpandas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T03:09:41.448Z","cooked":"

There’s a few things you could do:

  1. You could go with the two MAX planetary setup that thrifty shows on their elevator design
  2. There might be another vendor that has a gearbox ratio that suits your needs better
  3. If you aren’t scared of pneumatics investing in a shifting gearbox to increase the ratio when you climb could be feasible
  4. You could mess around and see if you could design your own gearbox with a more desirable gear ratio, it shouldn’t be too complicated but it can be hard if you or whoever CADs on your team hasn’t done it before or you don’t have the materials on hand.
  5. You could go for a separate climbing mechanism
  6. Probably a stretch but it does seem the WCP CC was able to lift it’s robot with a 5:1 gearbox ratio. They use two krakens but they also hang from their second stage which I believe multiplies the effective weight the motors are lifting. So you could try lifting with the two NEOs at 6.88 and hope for the best. This one definitely has the least guarantee of working though.
  7. Buy some extra powerful motors if you can afford it
  8. Option 8
